abstract.text: Information about a person participating in a SiriKit interaction.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: objects to represent people with many different roles, including the sender or recipient of calls and messages, the payer or payee of a financial transaction, or the driver of a vehicle. You also use person objects to identify the corresponding contact in your app and to communicate information about that contact back to SiriKit.
When resolving the parameters of an intent, use any provided

objects to identify the corresponding contacts in your app. A person object contains information provided by the initial request, which could be as little as a single name spoken by the person interacting with Siri. After identifying the contact, create a new
object and fill it with the information that you need to identify that contact again later. For example, you might specify a value for
property that contains the information about how your app identifies that contact.

When resolving the identities of contacts, SiriKit leverages the information in the device owner’s contacts database when that information is available. If the owner denies your app access to their contacts, SiriKit can’t use that information, which might cause many properties of a person object to be
protocol, though, SiriKit still populates the
property with what the person interacting with Siri said, and you can use that information to try to identify the contact. For more information about that protocol, see
To provide the best experience, especially when donating instances of
, assign a value to a person’s
if they exist in the device owner’s contacts database. Otherwise, assign a value to the
property that identifies the person in your app. When attempting to resolve a message recipient or call contact, prefer to use the people Siri adds to the

abstract.text: Empower people to customize interactions for your app on their device.
Information about a person participating in a SiriKit interaction.
The additional handles that Siri may use to identify the person.
The Contacts database identifier for the person.
The unique identifier that your app uses to identify the person.
The person’s formatted name.
The unique identifier that your app assigned to the user.
An image of the person.
Creates a person object with the specified display name and contact information.
Creates a person object with the specified display name and contact information.
Creates a person object with the specified name and contact information.
Creates a person with the specified name and contact information.
Creates a person with the specified name, contact, and alias information.
Creates a person with information Siri can use to suggestion the person at appropriate times.
Creates a person with information that indicates whether the person is the user of the device.
Creates a person that includes required metadata for messaging intents.
Creates a person with the specified name, contact, and relationship information.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the person is a contact suggestion.
A Boolean value indicating whether the person is the user of the device.
The individual components of the person’s full name.
The unique handle that your app assigns to the person.
The relationship between this person and the person using the device.
The list of matches Siri provides for you to resolve or disambiguate.
The type of contact information to donate with interactions.
The identifying information for a user of your app.
Constants describing how the person handle relates to the user.
Constants indicating the relationship between the person using the device and another person.
Constants indicating how to display the person’s identity.
The person assigned to a reservation.
Identifying information about a driver of a ride service.
A request to send a message to the designated recipients.
Pronunciation hints for strings used in a spoken interface.
The phrase identified by Siri.
A request to start an audio or video call with one or more users.
Review unsupported symbols and their replacements.
Fulfill the intent and provide feedback to SiriKit about what you did.
Donate app-specific content, use Siri’s contact suggestions, and adopt the latest platform features to create a more consistent messaging experience.

doc://com.apple.sirikit/documentation/Si.title: Improving interactions between Siri and your messaging app

abstract.text: Validate the parameters of an intent and make sure that you have the information you need to continue.

abstract.text: The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A type whose values can be implicitly or explicitly copied.
